metadata.title: Fabrication of carbon-coated Na/Fe@C nanorods using soybean straw for efficient oxygen evolution reaction catalysts

Fig. 1 (a, b) SEM images of Na/Fe@C at different magnifications and corresponding EDS mapping images (g). (c,d) TEM image and (e,f) HRTEM image of Na/Fe@C. Scheme 1 Table 1 BET results of the samples. Table 1 Samples Specific surface area (m2 g − 1) Pore volume (cm3 g − 1) Na@C 33.24 0.0012 Fe@C 243.39 0.0574 Na/Fe@C 84.92 0.0282 500 30.95 0.0026 700 15.98 0.0020 900 15.53 0.0011 Fabrication of carbon-coated Na/Fe@C nanorods using soybean straw for efficient oxygen evolution reaction catalysts Yuanrong Ye Data curation Writing – original draft Xin Zhao Writing – review & editing ⁎ Changwei Li Conceptualization Methodology Software Zongshun Zhang Visualization Investigation Huixin Zhang Visualization Investigation Junliu Zhang Supervision Shenghui Jiao Software Validation Honglei Chen Writing – review & editing ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Biobased Material and Green Papermaking, Qilu University of Technology, Shandong Academy of Sciences, Jinan 250353, China State Key Laboratory of Biobased Material and Green Papermaking Qilu University of Technology Shandong Academy of Sciences Jinan 250353 China State Key Laboratory of Biobased Material and Green Papermaking, Qilu University of Technology, Shandong Academy of Sciences, Jinan 250353, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process in water electrolysis requires high energy consumption. Reducing the interface limitations between metal and carbon precursors can significantly enhance the catalytic performance during the OER process. Because biomass exists in solid form, in this work, a carbon-coated Na/Fe@C nanorod OER electrocatalyst using soybean straw was prepared by coupling polyethylene glycol green liquefaction, in-situ doping, and carbonization route. The carbon coating increased the surface area and active site of the catalyst and prevented catalyst oxidation, thus extending the lifespan of the catalyst. The Na/Fe@C catalysts exhibited excellent OER catalytic activity. The overpotential at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and 100 mA cm−2 were 275 and 320 mV, respectively. Therefore, this study provides a promising strategy for preparing stable electrocatalysts and reducing OER energy consumption. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon-coated PEG liquefaction Electrocatalysis Soybean straw Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Electrocatalytic water splitting is a promising and efficient method for producing hydrogen owing to its advantages of cleanliness, high efficiency, and sustainability [1–5]. However, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a four-electron transfer process that needs a greater overpotential to meet the reaction conditions [6], thus increasing the energy requirement for electrolytic water splitting [7–10]. The water-splitting process is a main breakthrough for improving the transfer efficiency of multi-electrons and protons and for reducing the energy barrier of the OER process [11–15]. The efficiency of multi-electron and proton transfer experienced by the electrolyte during transport mainly depends on the porous structures and surface activity of the material [16–18]. Biomass-based carbon materials could use as the preferred precursor owing to their high specific surface area and tunable porous structures [19,20]. The specific porous characteristics of biomass-based carbon materials can effectively provide the location of the transport channel and the active sites [21,22]. Soybean straw is a common agricultural and forestry waste containing abundant C elements but is often ignored [23,24]. These C elements provide stable carbon sources and specific functional groups, which can adjust the electronic structure and surface activity of carbon via synergistic effect. Moreover, the choice of metal catalysts influences the energy barrier of the OER process [25,26]. Compared with precious metal-based catalysts, transition metal-based catalysts are efficient, stable, and cheap [27]. In addition, Fe can optimize the electronic structure of the active site, improve the conductivity, and promote the catalytic activity of the catalyst toward OER reactions [28–30]. The combination of biomass carbon and metal could adjust the electronic structure of the catalyst, thereby improving the performance [31]. But the interface limitation problem between biomass solid and metal powder is difficult to solve because biomass mainly exists in powder form and has low surface group activity [32]. The limitation problem may be solved by converting biomass solids into small liquid molecules with active groups [33]. Phenol liquefaction is an effective method for converting solid biomass into small liquid molecules [34,35]. However, phenol is limited by several challenges, including high toxicity and strong corrosivity. Thus, the efficient conversion of green liquefaction solvent is an important direction of biomass solid–liquid conversion. Before that, our research group preliminarily explored the liquefaction methods of green solution from alcohol, improved the solid-liquid conversion ratio and provide a liquid-phase environment for the efficient doping of metal powder [36]. In this work, a carbon-coated Na/Fe@C OER catalyst was successfully prepared by in-situ doping metal powder into carbon using green and nontoxic polyethylene glycol 400 (PEG400) as a solvent and waste soybean straw as raw material. The solid-liquid conversion of agricultural waste provided abundant doping sites for the effective doping of metal ions and mitigated the interface limitation between solid powder and metal. The carbon coating increased the surface area and active site density of the catalyst and inhibited catalyst oxidation and other issues, thus extending the lifespan of the catalyst. Furthermore, the porous structure of carbon and the crystallinity of the catalyst was effectively controlled by adjusting the carbonization temperature, which directly affected the morphology and structure of the nanorods, which in turn influenced the stability and activity of the catalyst. This study provides theoretical support for the efficient conversion of biomass and the highly valuable use of waste biomass in electrocatalytic. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The soybean straw was sieved (80 mesh, Lingshou-Hengchang company, Hengchang, China). Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Polyethyleneglycol 400 (PEG400), 25 wt.% of NH3·H2O, H2SO4, H3PO4, KOH, NaOH were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co. Ltd. Nickel foam (NF) was purchased from Innochem Technology Co. Ltd. All these reagents were analytical grade. 2.2 Synthesis of Na/Fe@C Precisely, 10 g soybean straw powder and 60 mL of PEG400 were placed into a three-necked flask, and catalyst (1 mL of H2SO4 and 2 mL of H3PO4) was added into the mixed solution and then further liquefied at 120 °C for 2 h under stirring. After the liquefied solution was cooled, its pH was neutralized with NaOH solution. Afterward, 4.04 g of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 10 mL of 25 wt.% NH₃·H2O were added to the solution (appropriate excess to maintain the alkaline environment) and then stirred and heated at 90 °C for 2 h; afterward, the mixed solution was removed, placed into the beaker, and dried in the oven, the Na, Fe doped liquefied products were prepared (LP-Na/Fe). The LP-Na/Fe were calcined at 800 °C in an N2-protected tube furnace for 2 h, and Na/Fe@C was prepared. To explore the impact of carbonization temperature on the catalyst, the LP-Na/Fe was also calcined at 500, 700, and 900 °C and named according to the corresponding temperatures. 2.3 Synthesis of Fe@C and Na@C For comparison, the sample Fe@C and Na@C were prepared without NaOH and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, respectively, following the procedure in Section 2.2. The carbonization temperature was anchored at 800 °C. 2.4 Characterization and electrochemical tests All the characterization and electrochemical tests are described in detail in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Analysis of structure, morphology, and composition As illustrated in Scheme 1 , the Na/Fe@C catalyst was synthesized by combining liquefaction and liquid-phase in-situ doping of Na+ and Fe+ from soybean straw. The solid biomass macromolecules were converted into liquid micromolecule under PEG400 alcohol green liquefaction solvent condition, and then Na+ and Fe+ introduce into the liquefied product (LP) to obtain LP-Na/Fe. Subsequently, the LP-Na/Fe was further dried and carbonized at 800 °C, obtaining the Na/Fe@C nanorod catalyst (see the Experimental section for details). The microstructure of Na/Fe@C was analyzed utilizing field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. 1 a and Fig. 1b, the rod-like structure of about 100 nm was clearly observed, along with surrounding block-shaped carbon particles. These nanorods were encapsulated inside the carbon particles, and the corresponding energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping images demonstrate the homogeneous distribution of elements including C, O, Na, Fe, and Si within the microstructure of Na/Fe@C (Fig. 1g). The morphology SEM analysis of Fe@C and Na@C are shown in the Fig. S1 (Supporting Information). Fe@C and Na@C nanorod structures were not similar to that of Na/Fe@C, further confirming the formation of species in Na/Fe@C as a result of the co-existence of Na and Fe with soybean straw. The TEM image (Fig. 1c and d) shows a uniform combination of sodium, iron, and liquefaction products with soybean straw. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) of Na/Fe@C nanorods is shown in Fig. 1e. Many uniformly distributed small bright circles were also observed, which may be caused by carbon defects formed by carbonization. In addition, the d spacing was 2.63 Å, corresponding to Na0.68Fe0.68Si0.32O2 (220), indicating that Na and Fe might exist in the form of sodium iron salt (Fig. 1f). The phase composition of the catalyst was further examined using an XRD (Fig. 2 a). Two strong peaks appeared at 2θ = 20.6° and 34.0° corresponded to (111) and (220) crystal planes of Na0.68Fe0.68Si0.32O2. However, the Fe@C and Na@C displayed weaker peak intensities, indicating that Na/Fe@C nanorods had excellent local crystallinity. In addition, to assess the effect of carbonization temperature on the catalyst, the Na/Fe@C samples at different carbonization temperatures were examined using XRD (Fig. 2b). The results showed that the peak of the catalyst was the sharpest at the carbonization temperature of 800 °C, which was the optimal temperature for the formation of Na0.68Fe0.68Si0.32O2 crystals. Raman spectra were used to further analyze the structural changes in different catalysts. The Raman spectra of Na/Fe@C, Fe@C, and Na@C were plotted in Fig. 2c, where the d-band and G-band peaks of carbon were close to 1350 and 1580, respectively. The ratio of d-band to G-band intensity was used to assess the defect degree of the sample [37]. The ratio difference between the three samples was small, which might be attributed to the addition of different metals. In addition, the degree of defects of Na/Fe@C catalysts at different carbonization temperatures was compared in Fig. 2d. The largest ID/IG was observed at 800 °C carbonization temperature, indicating that the catalyst had the highest degree of defects. The higher degree of defects could accelerate the penetration of ions in the electrolyte. Using N2 adsorption/desorption tests, the samples' specific surface area and pore size distribution were described. According to Table 1 , in addition to Fe@C, Na/Fe@C showed a greater specific surface area of 84.92 m2 g − 1. However, Fe@C has the largest specific surface area due to the presence of fewer formed crystals, and the surface area mainly comes from carbon. In Na/Fe@C, the reaction between Na and Fe results in the occupation of some carbon pores by crystals, the existence of these crystals reduces the specific surface area of carbon. Fig 2e and Fig. S2a (Supporting Information) show type I isotherm and rapid nitrogen absorption, a characteristic of microporous materials. The pore size distribution curve (Figs.2f and Fig. S2b, Supporting Information) confirmed the presence of numerous micropores and mesopores in catalysts, among which the proportion of mesopores was the highest. However, Na/Fe@C had a certain proportion of macropores, with a pore size of about 60 nm. This proportion of macropores can accelerate the penetration of the electrolyte. A reasonable proportion of macropores, mesopores, and micropores can provide good conductivity and facilitate the transfer of protons and electrons between each other. The larger specific surface area and macropore volume promoted ion penetration and exposed more active sites for electrochemical reactions [38,39]. We further analyzed the valence and chemical bonds of Na/Fe@C, Fe@C, and Na@C using XPS. The full spectra of the three samples are shown in Fig. 3 a. Fe@C displayed a strong Fe peak, Na@C displayed a Na peak, Na/Fe@C sample exhibited significant Fe and Na peaks, indicating the successful complex of sodium and iron. The C and O elements were bonded in the form of CC, CO, C = O, and CO-C (Figs. 3b and 3c). Na/Fe@C exhibited a strong Auger peak of Na at 536.7 eV, which could be attributed to the electron ionization of Na. Fig. 3d displays the high-resolution spectra of the Fe 2p orbitals of Na/Fe@C and Fe@C, which reveal that Fe in two samples was mainly present in the form of Fe2+and Fe3+ and present in Na/Fe@C in the form of Fe0. In addition, Fe3+ shifted to the high field direction by about 1 eV for Na/Fe@C, which might be attributed to the loss of electrons of Fe element or the transfer of electrons of Fe element to Na, which occurred after the introduction of Na into the system. The results of SEM, TEM, and XRD revealed that the presence of C and O could improve the surface wettability of the sample, the short-range disordered polycrystalline phase of the Na/Fe@C sample could provide an ion transport channel, and the electron-rich Na/Fe could promote electron transfer. The synergistic effect of soybean straw and Na/Fe metal could enhance water decomposition ability in the electrocatalytic process. 3.2 Electrochemical OER performance In 1 m KOH, the OER catalytic performance was assessed using a conventional three-electrode setup. As shown in Fig. 4 a, Na/Fe@C exhibited excellent OER catalytic activity: the overpotential at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and 100 mA cm−2 were 275 and 320 mV, which was much lower than Na@C and Fe@C (Fig. 4c). This significant enhancement of OER activity can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the compounds synthesized with Fe and Na. In addition, the highest OER activity of Na/Fe@C at 800 °C was attributed to the low graphitization degree of the sample when the carbonization temperature was relatively low, and the pore structure was not conducive to the transfer of electrons in the electrolyte. During carbonization at 900 °C, the pore structure of the sample was destroyed under high-temperature conditions, thus decreasing the surface area, thereby hindering the transfer and permeation of electrolytes. The reaction kinetics of different samples was investigated using the Tafel slope (Fig. 4b). The Na/Fe@C exhibited the lowest Tafel slope of 77.08 mV dec−1 compared with Fe@C (215.92 mV dec−1) and Na@C (320.11 mV dec−1), revealing the fastest reaction kinetics of Na/Fe@C. EIS impedance was used to describe the interface charge transfer resistance (Rct) between the catalyst and electrolyte. According to Fig.4d, Na/Fe@C shows the smallest Rct value, indicating that it has the fastest electron transfer rate. Electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) plays an important role in OER performance. We performed cyclic voltammetry tests to determine the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl) at different scan rates (Fig. S3 Supporting Information), and evaluated the ECSA of the catalyst accordingly. Fig. 4e shows the relationship between the corresponding current density and the scanning rate of the prepared catalyst. Na/Fe@C has the largest Cdl (54.22 mF cm−2), which is significantly larger than other samples. It is further shown that Na/Fe@C has the largest ECSA (1355.5 cm2) and exposes more active sites (Table S1 Supporting Information), which is beneficial to obtain excellent OER performance. More active sites were generated from the combination of soybean straw and metal, which provided excellent mass transfer channels. Moreover, appropriate carbonization conditions created a larger surface area and a reasonable pore size distribution, facilitating better electrolyte penetration into the active site. The stability of the catalyst in the reaction process is crucial. The Na/Fe@C composite exhibited excellent stability in the OER process (Fig. 4f). After 24 h of continuous operation, the current density retention rate of OER was 91%, and there was only a 15 mV decrease in overpotential before and after the i-t-test. Compared with similar catalysts reported in current research, our catalyst is at an advanced level (Table S2, Supporting Information). However, there is still room for improvement compared with some top-tier catalysts, such as fine-tuning the thickness of the carbon coating, controlling the porosity, and optimizing the crystal lattice oxygen defects. To further understand the structural characteristics of Na/Fe@C after OER test, the SEM images and high-resolution XPS spectra of Na/Fe@C after OER test were tested. The results show that after the OER test, the morphology of Na/Fe@C does not change significantly, and it still contains rod-like Na0.68Fe0.68Si0.32O2 and block-like C (Fig. 5 a). In the high-resolution XPS spectrum, Fig. 5b shows that C still exists in the form of CC, CO-O and C = O, which is consistent with the expectation. Unexpectedly, the Metal-O peak appears in the O 1 s peak, which is due to the oxidation of Fe0 during the OER process (Fig. 5c). Compared with that before the test, the disappearance of Fe0 in Fig. 5d is consistent with the change of O 1 s spectrum, which proves that Fe0 is not the main active substance in Na/Fe@C. These results further support that the catalytic activity of Na/Fe@C is mainly due to the synergistic effect of rod-like crystals and C in the OER reaction. The general OER mechanism of Na/Fe@C catalyst under alkaline conditions can be described in four steps: 1 Adsorption of hydroxide ions (OH−) on the catalyst surface: (1) OH− + M → M-OH + e− 2 Formation of active oxygen species (OOH*) through water oxidation: (2) M-OH + OH− → M-O + H2O + e− 3 Generation of O2 through the decomposition of active oxygen species: (3) M-O + OH− → M-OOH + e− 4 Desorption of oxygen gas from the catalyst surface: (4) M-OOH + OH−→ O2 + H2O + e− + M Where M is the active sites on the electrocatalyst surface. In general, the presence of Na0.68Fe0.68Si0.32O2 in Na/Fe@C promotes the initial adsorption of OH− and the breaking of OH bonds. This can be attributed to the high valence states of Fe. In addition, the coated bulk carbon particles are beneficial to promote the adsorption of OH- and the desorption of O2 during OER. 4 Conclusion In summary, a highly efficient, stable, and unique carbon-coated nanorod structure OER electrocatalyst was successfully fabricated using the PEG liquefaction method. Furthermore, the crystallinity of the nanorods was effectively regulated by controlling the carbonization temperature to achieve the desired morphology and structure, thereby enhancing the activity and stability of the catalyst. The rod-shaped crystal structure with a high surface area and more edge positions provided the main active sites for catalytic reactions. Additionally, the carbon-coated structure prevented the oxidation of the catalyst and increased the number of active sites. The coupling of nanorod and carbon coating structure enhanced the stabilization and performance of catalytic reactions. The OER potentials of our nanorod catalysts at 10 mA cm−2 and 100 mA cm−2 were 275 mV and 320 mV, respectively, outperforming most of the similar catalysts. Hence, this study described an approach for combining metal and biomass precursors through transforming solid–liquid bonding to liquid–liquid bonding. The concept of using solid–liquid transformation to bind metals through carbon precursor is important in achieving long-term stability and high efficiency of catalysts for energy conversion. coredata.dc:description: The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process in water electrolysis requires high energy consumption. Reducing the interface limitations between metal and carbon precursors can significantly enhance the catalytic performance during the OER process. Because biomass exists in solid form, in this work, a carbon-coated Na/Fe@C nanorod OER electrocatalyst using soybean straw was prepared by coupling polyethylene glycol green liquefaction, in-situ doping, and carbonization route. The carbon coating increased the surface area and active site of the catalyst and prevented catalyst oxidation, thus extending the lifespan of the catalyst. The Na/Fe@C catalysts exhibited excellent OER catalytic activity. The overpotential at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and 100 mA cm−2 were 275 and 320 mV, respectively. Therefore, this study provides a promising strategy for preparing stable electrocatalysts and reducing OER energy consumption.
coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of carbon-coated Na/Fe@C nanorods using soybean straw for efficient oxygen evolution reaction catalysts
